content: wagon wheel knot bag designed by lisa hounshell since there are special techniques for continuously working the motifs in this bag you will need to be familiar with the basics of breakaway crochet therefore if you have not done so already please refer to the following resources before you attempt this project ● for the basic concept and techniques start by downloading the free training wheels primer ebook from ravelry and/or watching the quick start tutorial breakaway crochet method video on youtube ● for a tutorial on working with wagon wheel motifs see this youtube video ● for a tutorial for this specific project please watch this youtube video ● for more information please keep in touch i will be publishing free patterns in my ravelry pattern shop lisa hounshell designs as they become available subscribe to my youtube channel https //youtube com/@breakawaycrochet to be notified of new video tutorials materials yarn jemark 4 ply crochet cotton - 2 balls each ball = 273 yards / 250 meters 1 76 ounces / 50 grams hook us size c/2 2 75mm 12 stitch markers 3 that are the same color 9 that are different in color to the first 3 for example 3 yellow markers the rest in any color other than yellow 1 measurements height including long handle 9 / 23cm width 12 / 30cm stitch gauge single_crochet 26 sts and 30 row = 4 / 10cm abbreviations us terminology ww wagon wheel motif slip_stitch slip_stitch chain chain single_crochet single_crochet dtr double treble_crochet fdtr floating treble_crochet - yarn over 3 times make a floating ring yarn over pull through 2 loops 4 times join work a slip_stitch in the first ch2 space behind the hook pattern notes this is a bucket-style bag which is built up from an oval-shaped base to make this a japanese knot bag work one long handle and one short one alternatively you can substitute the short handle for another long handle this bag is made entirely of wagon wheel ww motifs since all wws are worked continuously there is a specific sequence to follow when adding each ww the beginning sequence is a sort of spine that contains the first partial wws of each row after the beginning sequence 3 base wws are worked and then surrounded by 2 more row of wws once the base is finished continue working row of wws incorporating the wws of the spine as you go to build up the sides of the bag the last step is to work around the top edge of the bag adding in the handles at the same time the video gives a much more thorough demonstration of each of these steps 2 instructions unless otherwise stated all stitches are worked into the current floating ring beginning sequence 1 begin first ww fdtr ch2 dtr 4 times ch2 2 begin 6 more wws fdtr ch1 join ch1 dtr ch2 6 times 6 times 7 wws started in total 3 work 3 base wws
